title: 103_hr4367
content: The "Pension Reform Act of 1993" may be cited as the short title for this legislation. It includes pension integration rules. The Pension Reform Act of 1993 extends integration rules to all accrued benefits and disallows integration for simplified employee pensions. Effective for plan years beginning on or after January 1, 2002, integration rules under section 401(a)(5) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 are amended, with certain subparagraphs repealed and redesignated. Additionally, subsection (l) of section 401 regarding nondiscriminatory coordination of defined contribution plans with OASDI is also repealed. SEC. 3. Application of minimum coverage requirements to separate lines of business. SEC. 3. Application of minimum coverage requirements to separate lines of business. Subsection (b) of section 410 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a special rule for cases where the employer operates a single line of business for a plan year. The trust must be designated by the employer as part of a plan benefiting all employees to qualify under section 401(a). There is a limitation on the line of business exception in section 410(b) of the Code. SEC. 4 eliminates a special vesting rule for multiemployer plans in the Internal Revenue Code and ERISA by amending certain paragraphs. SEC. 5 addresses the division of pension benefits upon divorce. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include a provision for the division of pension benefits upon divorce, requiring at least 50 percent of the marital share of the accrued benefit of the participant to cease being an accrued benefit of the spouse. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the division of pension benefits upon divorce, where at least 50 percent of the marital share of the accrued benefit of the participant becomes the accrued benefit of the divorced spouse. This benefit is determined and payable upon the retirement of the participant, the participant's death, or the termination of the plan, unless a qualified domestic relations order states otherwise. The plan is not required to provide any new benefits or increased benefits under this provision. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the division of pension benefits upon divorce, with specific conditions outlined in a qualified domestic relations order. This order may require the payment of benefits to the divorced spouse or their subsequent spouse in various forms, such as a qualified joint and survivor annuity. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for the division of pension benefits upon divorce through a qualified domestic relations order. Amendments include inserting references to paragraph (32) in various sections related to domestic relations orders and pension benefits. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allow for the division of pension benefits in case of divorce, ensuring that at least 50 percent of the marital share of the accrued benefit of the participant ceases to be an accrued benefit. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allow for the division of pension benefits in case of divorce. The accrued benefit of the participant becomes the accrued benefit of the divorced spouse, payable upon retirement, death, or plan termination, unless a qualified domestic relations order states otherwise. The plan is not required to provide new benefits or increased benefits, or pay benefits to the divorced spouse if they are already designated for another individual. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows for the division of pension benefits in case of divorce. A qualified domestic relations order can specify payment of benefits to the divorced spouse in the form of a joint and survivor annuity. The terms 'domestic relations order' and 'qualified domestic relations order' are defined, and the 'marital share' is calculated based on the period of time during the marriage between the spouse and the participant in the plan. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 allows for the division of pension benefits in case of divorce through a qualified domestic relations order specifying payment in the form of a joint and survivor annuity. The term 'qualified joint and survivor annuity' is defined in section 205(d) of the Act. Regulations under this subsection require consultation between the Secretary and the Secretary of the Treasury. The text discusses the necessary recognition of orders for compliance with pension benefit division in case of divorce under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. It includes amendments to paragraphs (3)(D)(iii) and (3)(H)(iii) to ensure compliance with subsection (e) regarding qualified domestic relations orders. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATES. The amendments made by this Act apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1995, except for section 2. Section 5 amendments only apply to divorces finalized in those plan years. Special rules apply to collectively bargained plans ratified before the Act's enactment date. The amendments made by this Act apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 1995, except for section 2. Plan amendments required by the Act must be made by the first plan year beginning on or after January 1, 1995. Retroactive application of plan amendments is allowed if the plan is operated in accordance with the Act's requirements. The plan must operate in accordance with the provisions of the first plan year to provide definite benefits or contributions. SEC. 7. CLARIFICATION OF CONTINUED AVAILABILITY OF REMEDIES RELATING TO MATTERS TREATED IN DOMESTIC RELATIONS ORDERS ENTERED BEFORE 1985. In cases where a prior domestic relations order before January 1, 1985 did not divide pension benefits between spouses or one spouse waived their rights without consent, or if the division of benefits was unequal, further court action may be necessary. Further court action may be necessary regarding domestic relations orders entered before January 1, 1985, as the Retirement Equity Act of 1984 does not require treating post-enactment orders differently solely based on their timing. Definitions in this section align with those in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. The term "pro rata share" of a spouse in a pension plan is 50% of the accrued benefit multiplied by a fraction representing the period of creditable service during the marriage. All pension plans where a person is a participant are considered as one plan for that person. SEC. 8 amends Section 2 of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 by making changes to subsections (c)(4) and (e)(5).
